H0.text: Prophase I is the phase during which the nuclear envelope begins to break down.

H1.text: Nitrogenase i is the phase during which the nuclear envelope begins to break down.

H2.text: Pasiphaë I is the phase during which the nuclear envelope begins to break down.

H3.text: Interphase is the phase during which the nuclear envelope begins to break down.

A4.text: the meiotic prophase ends with the spindle apparatus beginning to form, and the nuclear membrane beginning to break down

A5.text: The nuclear envelope stays intact during this process

A6.text: At the beginning of prometaphase in animal cells, phosphorylation of nuclear lamins causes the nuclear envelope to disintegrate into small membrane vesicles.

A7.text: Closed and open mitosis can be distinguished on the basis of nuclear envelope remaining intact or breaking down.

A8.text: animal cells undergo an 'open' mitosis, where the nuclear envelope breaks down before the chromosomes separate.

A9.text: In other eukaryotes (animals as well as plants), the nuclear membrane must break down during the prometaphase stage of mitosis to allow the mitotic spindle fibers to access the chromosomes inside.

A10.text: In eukaryotes such as yeast which undergo closed mitosis, the nuclear membrane stays intact during cell division.

A11.text: Animations show transport occurring through the nuclear envelope.

A12.text: a new nuclear membrane surrounds each haploid set.

A13.text: In prophase I, the nucleoli disappear, the nuclear membrane disintegrates into vesicles, and the meiotic spindle begins to form.

A14.text: The nuclear envelope begins to be broken down in this stage.

A15.text: Prophase is the first stage of division.

A16.text: After nuclear envelope breakdown in prometaphase, condensation proceeds further.

A17.text: During interphase, these fibers are confined within the nucleus, which has a diameter of only ~10–20 um.

A18.text: Interphase is the active portion of the cell cycle that includes G1, S, and G2 phases, where the cell grows, replicates its DNA, and prepares for mitosis, respectively.
